topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: LTSSM Monitor Command

body.p: LTMON supports two capture modes: fully capture and snapshot. In the fully capture mode, all LTSSM state changes are recorded and rolling over if the number of captured LTSSM states exceeds the buffer size. The start and stop of the fully capture can be controlled manually. In snapshot mode, all LTSSM state changes are recorded and stops automatically when the buffer of the captured LTSSM states is full. The start of the snapshot capture can be controlled by manual or triggered by the watch point of LTSSM states. The watch point supports to watch:

li.p: Source state to other state change
Other state to destination state change
Source state to destination state change

body.p: LTSSM states are divided into major states and minor states as same as the PCIe spec definition. Only major states changes are available for trigger condition in the watch point. The major state and/or minor state can be skipped in LTMON buffer when capturing.

In LTMON, the counter recording time for each LTSSM that stays in a state is configurable. The counter is composed of two parts, an 8 bit configurable lower counter called the counter tick, and a 17 bit higher counter. The counter tick defines the amount of clock cycles (2ns) that is needed from a single increment of the higher counter. The higher counter will increment every “counter tick + 1” clock cycles. The higher counter is recorded in the LTSSM state change entry log. When the counter tick is modified, a reset must be performed to apply the modification.
The LTMON can be accessed on a per port basis from FW CLI or multiple MRPC hosts using access permissions.
MRPC Command ID: 0x11

row.entry: Source state for trigger mode invalid

entry.p: Destination state for trigger mode invalid

body.p: The following table provides the LTSSM Monitor Sub-Commands:

table.title: LTMON Basic Configuration Sub-Command Input Data
LTMON Basic Configuration Sub-Command Input Data

body.p: This field should be 1 to perform basic configuration of LTMON.
This field indicates the physical port number.
This field is the LTMON lower counter limit bits used to count for every (N+1) clock cycle ((N+1)*2ns), where “N” is the higher timer counter.

p.b: Note: If this command is not executed to configure LTMON, the default setting is: 1) Wrap LTSSM State = 1; 2) Count Tick per Clock Cycle = 0xb; 3) LTSSM Minor State Ignore = 0x000; 4) LTSSM Major State Ignore = 0.

table.title: LTMON Clear Log Sub-Command Input Data
LTMON Clear Log Sub-Command Input Data

body.p: This field should be 2 to perform a LTMON clear log.
This field indicates the physical port number.

table.title: LTMON Watch Point Configuration Sub-Command Input Data

entry.p: TRIGGER_MOD (0:DISABLE,1:FROM SRC,2:TO DEST, 3:FROM SRC TO DEST)

table.title: LTMON Trigger Condition Configuration Sub-Command Input Data

body.p: This field should be 3 to configure the LTMON trigger condition.
This field indicates the physical port number.
This field defines watch point ID for the configured trigger condition.

strow.stentry: This indicates that the first independent watch point 0 will trigger for LTMON
This indicates that the second independent watch point 1 will trigger for LTMON

body.p: This field indicates the condition used in watch point for LTMON. Only the major states can be used for the source and destination state conditions.

strow.stentry: Watch point is triggered when LTSSM state is changing from a configurable source condition to any other state.
Watch point is triggered when LTSSM state is changing from any other state to a configurable destination condition.
Watch point is triggered when LTSSM state is changing from a configurable source state to the configurable destination condition.

body.p: This field indicates the source state used for triggering in LTMON.
This field indicates the destination state used for triggering in LTMON.

table.title: LTMON Capture Mode Configuration Sub-Command Input Data
LTMON Capture Mode Configuration Sub-Command Input Data

body.p: This field should be 4 to configure the LTMON mode.
This field indicates the physical port number.
This field indicates if the LTMON will operate in which mode. By default, LTMON is in full capture mode.

table.title: LTMON Status Get Sub-Command Input Data
LTMON Status Get Sub-Command Input Data

body.p: This field should be 5 to get the LTMON status.
This field indicates the physical port number.

table.title: LTMON Status Get Sub-Command Output Data
LTMON Status Get Sub-Command Output Data

body.p: This field indicates the count of the watch point 0 triggered.
This field indicates the count of the watch point 1 triggered.
This field indicates the number of valid LTSSM state change that is logged in the buffer.
This command freezes the LTMON new LTSSM state change that's recorded by ignoring all of the LTSSM major and minor state change. This command should be executed before and after LTMON log dump.
This field should be 6 to freeze or unfreeze LTMON.
This field indicates the physical port number.
This field is used to freeze or unfreeze LTMON.

table.title: LTMON Log Dump Sub-Command Input Data
LTMON Log Dump Sub-Command Input Data

body.p: This field should be 7 for a LTMON log dump.
This field indicates the physical port number.
This field indicates the index of the first log to dump.
This field indicates the number of logs to dump.

table.title: LTMON Log Dump Sub-Command Output Data

row.entry: LOG_0 (bit[31:15] unused | bit[14:13] link rate | bit[12:11] unused | bit[10:7] major state | bit[6:3]minor state | bit[2:0] unused)
LOG_0 (bit[31:26] unused | bit[25:0] timer count bits)
LOG_1 (bit[31:15] unused | bit[14:13] link rate | bit[12:11] unused | bit[10:7] major state | bit[6:3]minor state | bit[2:0] unused)
LOG_1 (bit[31:26] unused | bit[25:0] timer count bits)

body.p: In combination with the calculations from the counter tick ((counter tick + 1) * clock cycle (2ns)), this field indicates the time that LTSSM stays in a state.
4’h0 = DETECT 4’h1 = POLLING 4’h2 = CFG 4’h3 = L0 4’h4 = RECOVERY 4’h5 = DISABLE 4’h6 = LOOPBACK 4’h7 = HOT_RESET 4’h8 = TX_L0S 4’h9 = L1 4’hA = L2

4’h0 = DETECT_INACTIVE 4’h1 = DETECT_QUIET 4’h2 = DETECT_SPD_CHG0 4’h3 = DETECT_SPD_CHG1 4’h4 = DETECT_ACTIVE0 4’h5 = DETECT_ACTIVE1 4’h6 = DETECT_ACTIVE2 4’h7 = DETECT_P1_TO_P0 4’h8 = DETECT_P0_TO_P1_0 4’h9 = DETECT_P0_TO_P1_1 4’hA = DETECT_P0_TO_P1_2

4’h0 = POLLING_INACTIVE 4’h1 = POLLING_ACTIVE_ENTRY 4’h2 = POLLING_ACTIVE 4’h3 = POLLING_CFG 4’h4 = POLLING_COMP 4’h5 = POLLING_COMP_ENTRY 4’h6 = POLLING_COMP_EIOS 4’h7 = POLLING_COMP_EIOS_ACK 4’h8 = POLLING_COMP_IDLE

4’h0 = CFG_INACTIVE 4’h1 = CFG_US_LW_START 4’h2 = CFG_US_LW_ACCEPT 4’h3 = CFG_US_LN_WAIT 4’h4 = CFG_US_LN_ACCEPT 4’h5 = CFG_DS_LW_START 4’h6 = CFG_DS_LW_ACCEPT 4’h7 = CFG_DS_LN_WAIT 4’h8 = CFG_DS_LN_ACCEPT 4’h9 = CFG_COMPLETE 4’hA = CFG_IDLE
4’h0 = L0_INACTIVE 4’h1 = L0 4’h2 = L0_TX_EL_IDLE 4’h3 = L0_TX_IDLE_MIN

4’h0 = REC_INACTIVE 4’h1 = REC_RCVR_LOCK 4’h2 = REC_RCVR_CFG 4’h3 = REC_IDLE 4’h4 = REC_SPEED0 4’h5 = REC_SPEED1 4’h6 = REC_SPEED2 4’h7 = REC_SPEED3 4’h8 = REC_EQ_PH0 4’h9 = REC_EQ_PH1 4’hA = REC_EQ_PH2 4’hB = REC_EQ_PH3
4’h0 = DISABLE_INACTIVE 4’h1 = DISABLE0 4’h2 = DISABLE1 4’h3 = DISABLE2 4’h4 = DISABLE3

4’h0 = LOOPBACK_INACTIVE 4’h1 = LOOPBACK_ENTRY 4’h2 = LOOPBACK_ENTRY_EXIT 4’h3 = LOOPBACK_EIOS 4’h4 = LOOPBACK_EIOS_ACK 4’h5 = LOOPBACK_IDLE 4’h6 = LOOPBACK_ACTIVE 4’h7 = LOOPBACK_EXIT0 4’h8 = LOOPBACK_EXIT1
4’h0 = HOT_RESET_INACTIVE 4’h1 = HOT_RESET 4’h2 = HOT_RESET_MASTER_UP 4’h3 = HOT_RESET_MASTER_DOWN
4’h0 = TX_L0S_INACTIVE 4’h1 = TX_L0S_IDLE 4’h2 = TX_L0S_TO_L0 4’h3 = TX_L0S_FTS0 4’h4 = TX_L0S_FTS1
4’h0 = L1_INACTIVE 4’h1 = L1_IDLE 4’h2 = L1_SUBSTATE 4’h3 = L1_TO_L0
4’h0 = L2_INACTIVE 4’h1 = L2_IDLE 4’h2 = L2_TX_WAKE0 4’h3 = L2_TX_WAKE1 4’h4 = L2_EXIT 4’h5 = L2_SPEED

section.p: The following is an example of using the LTMON commands.

ol.li:
LTMON configuration
Port 16, disable wrap, count tick is (22 + 1) clock cycles, not ignore major state, not ignore minor state
Write address 0 with data: 0x16001001 0x000000
Write address 2048 with data: 17

LTMON reset
Reset LTMON of port 16
Write address 0 with data: 0x1002
Write address 2048 with data: 17

Configure LTMON trigger condition
Port 16, trigger condition 0, from "Polling - 1" to "Cfg - 2"
Write address 0 with data: 0x03001003 0x0201
Write address 2048 with data: 17

Configure LTMON mode
Port 16, enable trigger mode
Write address 0 with data: 0x011004
Write address 2048 with data: 17

Get LTMON status
Port 16
Write address 0 with data: 0x1005
Write address 2048 with data: 17
2 bytes return data, so read 1 DW
Read address from 1024 for 1 DW data

Freeze LTMON
Port 16
Write address 0 with data: 0x011006
Write address 2048 with data: 17
Get ignoring bits, 3 bytes so read 1 DW.
Read address from 1024 for 1 DW data

Dump LTMON log
Port 16, read 32 entries from index 0.
Write address 0 with data: 0x20001007
Write address 2048 with data: 17
Read 32 log entries, each entry takes 1 DW, so read 32 DWs.
Read address from 1024 for 32 DWs data

Unfreeze LTMON
Port 16, no major and minor state ignored.
Write address 0 with data: 0x00001006 0x0000
Write address 2048 with data: 17

LTMON access permission release
Release access permission to port 16
Write address 0 with data: 0x1008
Write address 2048 with data: 17
